name: Delphi
shortDescription: Sacred oracle site of Apollo, center of the ancient world, where the Pythia delivered prophecies
fullDescription: Delphi was ancient Greece's most important oracle site, sacred to Apollo and considered the omphalos (navel) of the world. Located on the slopes of Mount Parnassus, Delphi housed the Temple of Apollo where the Pythia‚ÄîApollo's priestess‚Äîdelivered cryptic prophecies while in divine trance. According to myth, Apollo established the oracle after slaying the serpent Python who guarded the site. The sanctuary became a pan-Hellenic religious center where city-states consulted the oracle before major decisions regarding war, colonization, or legislation. The site featured the famous maxims 'Know Thyself' and 'Nothing in Excess' inscribed on Apollo's temple. Delphi also hosted the Pythian Games, second only to the Olympics in prestige, celebrating Apollo with athletic and musical competitions.

events.name: Slaying of Python
events.description: Apollo killed the serpent Python and established his oracle at Delphi

events.name: Oracular Consultations
events.description: City-states and individuals consulted the Pythia for guidance on crucial matters

events.name: Pythian Games
events.description: Pan-Hellenic athletic and musical competitions held every four years

mythologyContexts.usage: Primary oracle of Apollo; center of the ancient world (omphalos); site of the Pythia's prophecies; location of Pythian Games; spiritual center of Greek civilization

rituals.name: Oracular Consultation
rituals.description: Supplicants purified themselves, sacrificed, and received prophecies from the Pythia

rituals.name: Pythian Games
rituals.description: Athletic and musical competitions every four years honoring Apollo

rituals.name: Theoxenia
rituals.description: Festival hosting Apollo and Dionysus at Delphi

textReferences.context: Apollo establishes his oracle at Delphi after slaying Python
Detailed description of Delphi sanctuary and treasures
Discussion of the oracle's nature and prophecies

mythologyContexts.symbolism: Delphi symbolizes the intersection of divine and mortal realms‚Äîwhere human questions receive divine answers. As the omphalos (navel), it represents the world's spiritual center, the point of cosmic connection. The oracle's cryptic prophecies symbolize divine truth that requires human interpretation and wisdom‚Äîgods provide guidance but mortals must understand. Apollo's victory over Python represents order overcoming chaos, light conquering darkness, and civilization taming primal forces. The maxims 'Know Thyself' and 'Nothing in Excess' embody Greek philosophical ideals of self-awareness and moderation. Delphi represents humanity's eternal quest to glimpse the future and understand divine will.
mythologyContexts.culturalSignificance: Delphi was the religious and spiritual heart of ancient Greece, transcending city-state rivalries. The Delphic Amphictyony (league of neighboring states) protected the sanctuary, creating one of the earliest forms of international cooperation. Oracular pronouncements influenced major historical decisions‚Äîwars, colonization, constitutional changes. 'Delphic' entered language meaning ambiguous or obscure, referencing the oracle's cryptic style. The site influenced Western concepts of prophecy, divine communication, and sacred geography. UNESCO designated Delphi a World Heritage Site. Modern excavations revealed spectacular ruins attracting millions of visitors, keeping ancient spiritual traditions alive.

etymology.development: Earlier name: Pytho ‚Üí later Delphi (both names used in classical sources). Pytho connects to the serpent Python; Delphi to the womb/dolphin symbolism. The site name shifted as Apollonian cult supplanted earlier chthonic oracle.

originPoint.name: Delphi
originPoint.description: Sanctuary of Apollo at Delphi, on southwestern slopes of Mount Parnassus, Phocis, Central Greece. Archaeological site and ancient oracle center.

firstAttestation.description: Homeric Hymn to Apollo describes establishment of Delphic oracle

timelinePosition.context: Sacred site from Mycenaean period (c. 1400 BCE), became pan-Hellenic oracle center in Archaic period (c. 800-480 BCE)

keyMoments.significance: Apollo establishes oracle, supplanting earlier Earth goddess cult
Reorganization of Pythian festival as pan-Hellenic games
Athens consults oracle before Battle of Salamis
